metadata.title: Effects of catalyst composition on the ionic liquid catalyzed isobutane/2-butene alkylation
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

Effects of catalyst composition on the ionic liquid catalyzed isobutane/2-butene alkylation Ying Liu ⁎ Rui Li Hongjuan Sun Ruisheng Hu School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, University of Inner Mongolia, Hohhot, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering University of Inner Mongolia Hohhot China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 471 4992981. Graphical abstract Ionic liquid catalyzed isobutane/2-butene alkylation modified with metal compounds was studied. The catalytic selectivity of the modified IL is determined by the catalyst composition. The complexation of CuAlCl4 with 2-butene can increase the internal isobutane-to-olefin ratio during the alkylation reaction, which results in the better selectivity of the modified IL. When ionic liquids containing transition metal complexes, high quality alkylates could be obtained. Ionic liquid catalyzed isobutane/2-butene alkylation modified with metal compounds was studied. The effect of catalyst composition on the alkylation selectivity was investigated. 27Al NMR, ESI-MS, and FTIR spectra reveal that the catalytic selectivity of the modified ionic liquid is probably determined by the catalyst composition rather than by the acid strength. The complexation of transition metal with 2-butene can increase the internal isobutane-to-olefin ratio of feed during the alkylation reaction, which results in the better selectivity of the modified ionic liquid. The best ionic liquid catalysts were those containing CuAlCl4 complexes, giving the alkylate with 87.5wt% trimethylpentanes and a calculated research octane number (RON) of 100.5. Keywords Alkylation Isobutane 2-Butene Ionic liquid 1 Introduction Alkylation of isobutane with C3–C5 alkenes is an important industrial process for the production of high-octane gasoline with low residual vapor pressure. To date, only sulfuric acid (H2SO4) and hydrofluoric acid (HF) have been extensively commercially applied for the alkylation due to economic considerations [1,2]. However, acid sludge treatments and safety protection may be the most difficult problems that restrict the commercial application of the two acids [3]. Due to the growing awareness of environmental issues, it is necessary to use some safer and easily regenerable materials to catalyze the reaction. Molecular sieves and heteropolyacids are known to possess high catalytic activities and selectivities. These solid acids have been studied as potential catalysts for alkylation of isobutane with alkenes for years. Despite the potential benefits presented by the solid acids, they have still not achieved commercial use as alkylation catalysts due to the fast catalyst decay [4]. In order to enhance the lifetime of solid catalysts, supercritical fluid like supercritical isobutane has been used as media for solid acid catalyzed alkylation [5]. Liquid superacid catalysts such as ionic liquids (IL) are also receiving increased attention [1,6]. The main advantages arising from the use of IL are their clean catalytic properties for alkylation processes. Additionally, the physical and chemical properties of IL can be readily tuned by using different organic cations or inorganic anions. Compared with solid acids, most IL can maintain high catalytic activity during the whole alkylation reaction without carbon deposition problems. Despite no IL has reached industrial application, the composite IL [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3–CuCl, which is a chloroaluminate IL modified with cuprous chloride, has been reported for the pilot-scale alkylation test [1]. It is well known that acid strength and catalyst composition will affect the formation of t-butyl cation (t-C4 +) and the rate of hydride transfer [7]. Thus, the acidity and composition of IL are probably the most important parameters affecting alkylation. Recently, influences of the IL acidity on isobutane/2-butene alkylation have been studied. When some metal salts are mixed with the chloroaluminate IL [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3, it is supposed that the change of Lewis acidic site in the IL that results in the alkylate quality increases dramatically [8,9]. Zhang et al. [10] also found that the addition of benzene to [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3 could obviously improve the alkylate composition. They consider that benzene leads to modify the Lewis acidity of [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3, and the modification is presumably beneficial for alkylation because it inhibits the side reactions. Additionally, it is believed that increasing the concentration of HCl or the molar fraction of AlCl3 in [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3 will increase its acidity. Such an increase leads to an increase in the butene conversion and a decrease in the rate of side reactions. Adding water in an acidic molten salt can play a similar role to HCl [11]. For non-chloroaluminate based IL, a dramatic enhancement of the catalytic effect was observed when the IL containing the SbF6 − anion [12,13]. Using the binary mixture of acidic imidazolium IL and sulfuric or triflic acid has the similar effects [14]. The better catalytic performances of such catalysts maybe result from the complex acidity and solubility effects of IL. However, the aforementioned studies were essentially focused on discussing the effects of acidity and acid strength, it is necessary to investigate more characteristics of the catalyst composition to better understand the behavior of IL during the alkylation. In this study, we report our studies on the effect of the IL composition on the alkylation of isobutane with 2-butene. Chloroaluminate IL [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3, [BMIm]Br–AlCl3, and [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3 were used as catalysts in the studies. They were also modified with transition metal salts, metal complexes, and metallic oxides. The catalytic selectivities of the IL catalysts were compared with those obtained in pure strong acids under the identical reaction conditions. The acid strength and composition of the IL were also investigated by mean of FTIR, 27Al NMR, and electrospray ionization-mass spectrometry (ESI-MS). 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts Sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 98wt%) and trifluoromethanesulfonic acid (CF3SO3H) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent (SCRC). Before use, CF3SO3H were distilled under dry nitrogen. The triethylamine hydrochloride ([Et3NH]Cl), chloride or bromide salts of the 1-butyl-3-methyl- imidazolium cations ([BMIm]Cl, [BMIm]Br) were all obtained from Sigma–Aldrich Chemical Company and dried under vacuum at 383K. [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3, [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3, and [BMIm]Br–AlCl3 chloroaluminate IL were prepared and characterized using methods described earlier [15]. The molar ratio of AlCl3 to organic salt is 1.8:1 in this work. The IL/additive systems were prepared by directly adding additives to the chloroaluminate IL. Additives included transition metal salts, metal complexes, and metallic oxides. They were added to the IL at the beginning of the alkylation reaction. Most of IL/additive catalysts were suspension. According to the literature preparation [16,17], the mixed-metal chloride CuAlCl4 can be readily synthesized in high yield from the melt of CuCl and AlCl3 (<523K). [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3–CuCl, [BMIm]Br–AlCl3–CuCl, and [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3–CuCl were composite IL used in this study. They were prepared by introducing cuprous chloride to the chloroaluminate IL [18]. In a typical method of preparing composite IL, anhydrous aluminum chloride (1.8mol) was slowly added to a round-bottomed flask containing dry 1-butyl-3-methyl- imidazolium chloride (1mol) under a nitrogen atmosphere at 383K. After formation of chloroaluminate ionic liquid, 0.5mol of cuprous chloride was added to the above ionic liquid. The reaction mixture was stirred at 383K overnight to allow a complete homogenization of the resulting ionic liquid. 2.2 Characterization of ionic liquids Acidity characterizations were carried out by infrared spectroscopy using pyridine as the acid probe at room temperature, along with a Bio-Rad high-resolution FTIR spectrometer (FTS-40). All spectra were manipulated by Bio-Rad Win-IR software. The samples were prepared by mixing pyridine and IL in a volume ratio of 5:1, and smeared into liquid films on KBr windows. The 27Al NMR measurements were carried out on a Bruker WB-400 AMX spectrometer to investigate the difference of anions. The spectra were obtained at 130.32MHz with a preacquisition delay time of 0.5s. The 27Al NMR chemical shifts were referenced to an external Al(H2O)6 3+ standard. Characterization of the IL anions was achieved using a negative mode of electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS). ESI-MS was recorded on a Thermo Finnigan LCQDeca XP Plus quadrupole ion trap instrument on samples dissolved in methanol. 2.3 Procedure and analysis Isobutane and 2-butene were commercial products from China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) with 99% purity and used without further purification. Alkylation reactions were carried out in a liquid-phase pressure vessel (100mL) with a liquid inlet. A mechanical stirrer with a fixed impeller on the shaft provided agitation at 1200r/min. The catalyst (e.g., 15mL) was put into the reactor at first. After stirring, the liquid feed (a mixture of isobutane/2-butene in a 7.5:1 molar ratio) was charged into the reactor by means of a plunger pump at a rate of 500mL/h. The reaction temperature was controlled at 298K by a water bath with temperature controller. When the pressure of the reactor was higher than 0.4MPa, we stopped the pump and stirrer. The total reaction time was about 30min. The product and catalyst were decanted from the reactor and settled for 30min. The product was fractionated to remove isobutane and distilled in a Claisen flask. Aliquots of the hydrocarbon phase were withdrawn for analysis. The investigation for the isobutane-to-olefin (I/O) molar ratio of isobutane/2-butene feed in the toluene-CuAlCl4 system was also performed in the alkylation reactor. In a typical experiment, the toluene-CuAlCl4 (15mL) mixture was introduced into the reactor at room temperature. A mixture of isobutane/2-butene (initial I/O=7.5) from the feed vessel was pumped into the stirred (1200r/min) reactor. The agitation was continued for 30min, and then the liquid outlet at reactor was opened. The excess isobutane/2-butene mixture was vented at room temperature for analyzing the final molar ratio of isobutane to 2-butene. The alkylate samples were sent to a gas chromatograph (Hewlett-Packard, 6890). The GC column used for separation was a Supelco Petrocol DH capillary column (50m×0.1mm×0.1mm). Initial qualitative identifications of the products were accomplished with the help of a gas chromatograph (Hewlett-Packard, 5890 Series II) equipped with a mass spectrometer (Hewlett-Packard, 5972 Series II column). The research octane number (RON) of alkylate was calculated, according to the method applied in Ref. [7,11]. The gas samples of isobutane/2-butene were also sent to the Hewlett-Packard 6890 GC for investigating the change of I/O ratio of feed. Except the injection mode, the analysis conditions of gas samples were as the same as the alkylate samples. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Alkylation reactions under identical conditions The reaction mechanism of acid catalyzed isobutane/2-butene alkylation is a chain process occurring through carbocation intermediates [19]. The protonation of 2-butene can form t-butyl cations (t-C4 +), which initiate the alkylation reaction. A t-C4 + cation is added to a 2-butene molecule to form a 2,2,3-trimethylpentane carbocation (2,2,3-TMP+). Some of 2,2,3-TMP+ cations will isomerize to the corresponding 2,2,4-trimethylpentane carbocations (2,2,4-TMP+). The desired product 2,2,4-trimethylpentane (2,2,4-TMP) is mainly obtained by intermolecular hydride transfer between isobutane and 2,2,4-TMP+. The hydride transfer also generates a new t-butyl cation that will react with another 2-butene molecule. Many side reactions that lead to forming low RON products are always accompanying with the main reaction. The intermediate TMP+ cation often competes with t-C4 + cation in the hydrocarbon-phase and adds to another 2-butene molecule forming i-C12 +, i-C16 + and so on. Most C12 and heavier alkanes are the results of the hydride transfer of these large cations. Strong acid can readily cleave C12 + and C16 + cations to the C5 +–C7 + and dimethylhexane cations (DMH+) through β-scissions [20]. These carbocations are believed to be the major source of light ends (C5–C7 alkanes) and dimethylhexanes (DMH) [21]. It can be easily understood that in a complex reaction such as alkylation, the reaction conditions are going to play an important role in determining product distribution. In order to compare our results using chloroaluminate IL as the catalysts with conventional liquid acids, firstly, alkylation reactions were performed using H2SO4 and CF3SO3H catalysts. In Table 1 , a comparison of the product composition for different catalysts is given. Despite the different types of catalyst used, under the identical reaction condition some common features were observed in the product composition: the predominance of C8 in a spectrum of C5–C9+ paraffins, the low content of olefinic products, and the high selectivity for trimethylpentanes (TMP). The close similarity in the alkylate produced from different catalysts leads to the conclusion that the same chain mechanism is operative on different types of catalyst. When [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3 and H2SO4 were employed as catalysts, more light ends (C5–C7) and heavier ends (C9+) were observed in the alkylates. By contrast, more TMP was formed using CF3SO3H or [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3 than that obtained with H2SO4 or [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3. This result may be due to the solubility of isobutane in acid phase. A larger amount of isobutane is considered to dissolve in CF3SO3H or [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3 than in H2SO4 or [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3, which results in fewer side reactions. However, the obtained RON value of our catalysts was lower than that reported in literature, which may be a result of inefficient mixing of the hydrocarbon and acid phases under our reaction conditions. The higher reaction temperatures of the alkylation reactions also lower the quality of alkylate. 3.2 Effects of metal compounds on alkylation reaction The alkylation of isobutane/2-butene was studied using modification of the IL by introducing various metal compounds. Tables 2 and 3 show the product distribution from alkylation reactions using modified [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3 and [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3 as catalysts, respectively. The addition of additive obviously affected the composition of the alkylate obtained. Results of [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3/additive and [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3–CuCl are summarized in Table 2. When metal compound additives were added to [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3, TMP were the major components of the alkylate (>50wt%). DMH, light ends, and heavier ends were obtained as the relatively minor components, indicating alkylation reactions were predominant. Adding CuCl, AgCl, or ZnCl2 salt to the IL, a marked increase in TMP was observed and the amount of DMH and heavier ends was decreased. However, these additives seem to be less affected the amount of light ends. In addition, TMP content peaked when [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3–CuCl was used, which produced the lowest amount of light ends, DMH, and heavier ends. Thus, the composite IL [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3–CuCl gave the alkylate with the best quality. When isobutane/2-butene was alkylated by [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3 using metallic oxides as additives, the same products were obtained, with the distribution slightly shifted to a higher production of C9+ alkanes. Results of alkylation using [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3/additive as well as the composite IL [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3–CuCl as catalysts are given in Table 3. Changes in the product composition similar to the results shown in Table 2 were observed. With the addition of transition metal compounds to [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3, a lower amount of heavier ends and a higher amount of TMP were obtained, which increased the alkylate quality. The best alkylate was found again when the composite IL catalyzed the reaction. The RON difference between the cases of [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3 and [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3 systems was probably due to a lower dissolved ratio of isobutane in [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3 than in [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3 [22]. 3.3 Effects of metal compound on IL composition To investigate the effect of metal compound on the IL composition, we studied the Al species of [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3 and [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3 systems using 27Al NMR characterization. The results are shown in Fig. 1 . On the basis of their chemical shifts, the two peaks in the spectrum of [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3 (Fig. 1(c)) can be assigned to AlCl4 − (97.1ppm) and Al2Cl7 − (103.1ppm) [23,24]. In contrast, AlCl4 − is the dominant Al species in [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3–CuCl sample (Fig. 1(d)), indicating the part of Al2Cl7 − be transformed to AlCl4 −. The appearance of a new peak at 92.0ppm is believed the resonance signal of CuAlCl5 −, the ion of AlCl4 − coordinating with CuCl [18]. For the [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3 sample, only one peak (103.1ppm, Al2Cl7 −) appears in the spectrum (Fig. 1(a)). But there are two peaks at 97.2ppm and 92.1ppm in the spectrum of [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3–CuCl (Fig. 1(b)), which are CuAlCl5 − and AlCl4 −, respectively. It is suggested that the change in anions, and therefore the composition of IL systems, is the main factor resulting in different catalytic performances of the systems. The higher amount of TMP obtained for the composite IL may be attributed to the appearance of CuAlCl5 −. More investigation had been done to further study the composition of IL. Unlike the IL samples for 27Al NMR detection, the IL samples for ESI-MS characterization had been used to catalyze the alkylation reaction. For the [BMIm]Br–AlCl3–CuCl sample, some new complex species like CuAlBrCl4 − and CuAlBrCl3 were detected in the spectrum (Fig. 2 (a)). CuAlCl5 − and CuAlCl4 species were also identified in the ESI-MS characterization of [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3–CuCl sample (Fig. 2(b)). 3.4 Effects of metal compound on acid strength For H2SO4 and HF catalysts, the composition of the acids is not the only factor affecting the quality of the alkylate. The change in acid strength will also result in producing the alkylates with different RON values. Thus, Bui [25] and Huang [9] are convinced that adding metal chlorides to [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3 will greatly affect the acid strength and enhance the catalytic performance of the IL. The higher amount of TMP, obtained for [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3/CuCl system, is likely to be a lower acid strength than that of the [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3. The FTIR analysis can investigate the change of Lewis acidities of IL by using pyridine as a molecular probe [26]. The degree of monotonic blue shift of the band near 1437cm−1 shows the increase in the Lewis acid strength and the height of the peak near 1535cm−1 represents the Brønsted acid strength [25]. Further study on the role of metal chloride on the acidity of IL was carried out using the same method (Fig. 3 ). The wavenumber of the band near 1437cm−1 increases from 1441.49cm−1 for [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3 (Fig. 3 (c)) to 1442.80cm−1 for [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3–CuCl (Fig. 3(d)), indicating that the Lewis acid strength slightly decreases. But the [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3 and [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3–CuCl samples almost have the same wavenumbers near 1437cm−1, which are 1442.01 (Fig. 3(f)) and 1441.98cm−1 (Fig. 3(e)), respectively. According to these results, the product distribution of the comparison IL samples should have very little difference. However, as Tables 2 and 3 shown, more TMP were obtained with the modified IL when compared to the net IL. In addition, the wavenumber bands for [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3 and [BMIm]Cl–ZnCl2 (Fig. 3(b)) near 1437cm−1 are also very close, but [BMIm]Cl–ZnCl2 cannot catalyze the alkylation reaction due to its weak acid strength. The Et3NHCl–AlCl3–CuCl and Et3NHCl–AlCl3 samples have almost identical peak areas at 1535cm−1, implying that they have the same Brønsted acid strength. 3.5 Effect of CuAlCl4 on alkylate composition The complex CuAlCl4 was used as the additive of IL to study its effect on the alkylate composition. Both little (2.5g) and more (5g) amount of CuAlCl4 were investigated and compared with those of net chloroaluminate IL systems (Table 4 ). The quality of alkylates was high for the IL/CuAlCl4 systems when compared to those obtained for the IL without Cu-Al complex. By increasing the amount of complex additive from 2.5 to 5g results, for the [Et3NH]Cl-AlCl3/CuAlCl4 system, in an increase of the TMP amount from 71.7 to 87.5. [BMIm]Cl-AlCl3/CuAlCl4 has a similar trend, but the TMP of [BMIm]Br-AlCl3/CuAlCl4 system is slightly increased from 70.1 to 83.1 due to the higher acid strength of [BMIm]Br-AlCl3 [15]. The potential recyclability of [BMIm]Cl-AlCl3 with CuAlCl4 as additive was also investigated in a continuous alkylation process. During the process, the alkylation product with excess isobutane was pumped out of the reactor every 0.5h for analysis. The results, given in Fig. 4 , show that the catalyst can be maintained good catalytic performance less than 3h. The catalyst's poor TMP selectivities after 3h may be due to the deactivation of chloroaluminate IL by the water from isobutane. 3.6 CuAlCl4 and 2-butene adsorption Transition metal complexes like CuAlCl4 and AgAlCl4 can be used as the selective separating agent for light olefins and paraffins separations [27]. The formation of electron donor/acceptor complexes between alkenes and some transition metals has long been known. Herberhold [28] satisfactorily explained the nature of the weak chemical bonding of olefin-metal complexes. The relationship between CuAlCl4 and 2-butene adsorption was examined by charging the liquid-phase isobutane/2-butene into the CuAlCl4/toluene solution. The condition of the 2-butene adsorption test was identical to the alkylation reaction (15mL toluene, 0.4MPa, agitation=1200r/min, and the initial I/O ratio of feed=7.5). Here, toluene was used as a solvent, and a series of different weights of CuAlCl4 was used to investigate the CuAlCl4 adsorption ability for the olefin. As Fig. 5 (a) shown, the final I/O ratio of isobutane/2-butene feed was increased when increasing the amount of CuAlCl4 in the toluene-CuAlCl4 system. This result suggests that the toluene-CuAlCl4 system could adsorb the olefin just because of the complexation of Cu(I)-butene. 3.7 Influence of isobutane-to-olefin ratio The isobutane-to-olefin ratio (I/O) of feed is another key aspect in alkylation reaction. Because the conditions that favor alkylation also favor polymerization of olefins, an excess of isobutane is always employed to promote the desired reaction. We would like to investigate how I/O ratio affected the alkylation product when using IL as catalysts. When isobutane was alkylated with 2-butene in a batch reactor (283K, 1200r/min, and 15mL [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3 catalyst), the trend of I/O ratio vs. alkylate distribution of [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3 was plotted in Fig. 5(b). With I/O ratio increasing, TMP markedly increased and a maximum in TMP yield was found at I/O=33. When high I/O ratios are fed, 2-butene has a higher probability of reacting with an isobutane molecule to form the desired product than of performing butene-butene polymerization [29]. It can be easily understood the results listed in Table 4. When [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3/CuAlCl4 or [BMIm]Cl–AlCl3/CuAlCl4 was used as the alkylation catalyst, 2-butene could be adsorbed by CuAlCl4 which increased the I/O ratio of the alkylation process. As the formation of complex between 2-butene and CuAlCl4, the hydride transfer between isobutane and TMP+ becomes more easily and generates more TMP product. However, further adding more CuAlCl4 (10g) to the IL decreases the quality of alkylates (Table 4). This could be explained by a lower interfacial area between the IL and hydrocarbon phases where alkylation reactions occurred [30]. 3.8 Metal compounds and 2-butene adsorption Munson et al. [31] have reported the separation of olefins from paraffins using IL solutions. In Table 5 , comparable trends of 2-butene adsorption are observed for transition metal-toluene systems. Although most transition metal compounds are not dissolved in toluene, toluene can be used as an IL simulant. Under identical conditions of the alkylation reaction, the systems were all found give a higher I/O ratio after operation, indicating that some other metal compounds could adsorb 2-butene of feed. According to the aforementioned chain mechanism, higher I/O ratio of feed will decrease the reaction probabilities of C8 + +CH3CH=CHCH3→C12 +, C16 + because of more isobutane molecules around C8 + cations. It seems to be an explanation for the better selectivities of composite IL and IL/metal compound systems. Commercially, internal circulation consists of circulating the reactor contents rapidly and introducing fresh isobutane into the circulating stream. Internal I/O ratios may be as high as 1 000:1[2]. In this study, although no fresh isobutane was charged into the IL/metal chloride system, the adsorption of the 2-buteneby the metal chloride that might dramatically increase the internal I/O ratio (Table 5) and produce the high quality alkylate (as the data listed in Tables 2 and 3). Similarly, the alkylates with higher RON values (Table 6 ) were obtained by[BMIm]Cl–AlCl3/metal complex systems just because the transition metal complexes could increase the I/O ratios. Reaction CuAlCl5 − →CuAlCl4 +Cl− must have been taken place in the alkylation of the composite IL, because the CuAlCl5 − and CuAlCl4 were detected in the ESI-MS spectrum of the used [Et3NH]Cl AlCl3–CuCl (Fig. 2). Such a transition helpsmore 2-buteneto beadsorbed by CuAlCl4. However, the best alkylate quality obtained with [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3–CuCl (Table 3) wasstill lower than that obtained using [Et3NH]Cl–AlCl3/CuAlCl4 (RON=100.5) or [BMIm]Br–AlCl3 (RON=98.6) as catalyst. This could be explained by a lower amount of CuAlCl4 in the composite IL, which results in a lower I/O ratio than that of the IL/CuAlCl4 system. 4 Conclusions Study of the effects of catalyst composition and acidity on IL catalyzed isobutane/2-butene alkylation, shows better product composition (indicated by the amount of TMP of the product) can be obtained when the IL systems modified with metal compounds. Adding a small amount of transition metal compound cannot significantly change the acid strength of the IL, but can increase the ratio of I/O of the reaction system. It is clear that the I/O of hydrocarbon phase will significantly affect the product composition of IL, and CuAlCl4 in IL can helpincrease the I/Oratio due to the Cu(I)-butene complexation. The trace amounts of Al-transition metal species like CuAlCl4, CuAlBrCl3 are detected in the IL catalysts, which adsorb the 2-butene in the alkylation process. The better TMP selectivity of the modified IL can be attributed to the formation of complexes between 2-butene and transition metals. coredata.dc:description: Ionic liquid catalyzed isobutane/2-butene alkylation modified with metal compounds was studied. The effect of catalyst composition on the alkylation selectivity was investigated. 27Al NMR, ESI-MS, and FTIR spectra reveal that the catalytic selectivity of the modified ionic liquid is probably determined by the catalyst composition rather than by the acid strength. The complexation of transition metal with 2-butene can increase the internal isobutane-to-olefin ratio of feed during the alkylation reaction, which results in the better selectivity of the modified ionic liquid. The best ionic liquid catalysts were those containing CuAlCl4 complexes, giving the alkylate with 87.5wt% trimethylpentanes and a calculated research octane number (RON) of 100.5.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of catalyst composition on the ionic liquid catalyzed isobutane/2-butene alkylation
